content_hebrew: מה מזון מומלץ לטיפול בחסר יין? לחסר יין ממליצים מזונות מזינים ומלחחים: שורש מנה, שזיפים שחורים, זרעי שומשום שחור, פטריות שיטאקה, אצות, דלעת, בננות בוגרות, חלב סויה, אגוזים, ביצים. להימנע ממזון חריף, מטוגן, אלכוהול. KI3: מחזק יין כליות | KI6: מזין יין כליות ומחזק נוזלים | SP6: מזין דם ויין, מרגיע שורש מנה (Rehmannia glutinosa), שזיפים שחורים (Prunus nigra), זרעי שומשום (Sesamum indicum)

content_hebrew: אילו מזונות מחמירים חסר יין? מזונות חמים ויבשים מחמירים חסר יין: תבלינים חריפים (פלפל חריף, ג'ינג'ר יבש), מזון מטוגן, קפה, אלכוהול, בשר אדום, בצל, שום, בצל ירוק. LV2: מפזר חום ירוק | LI11: מפזר חום גוף כללי תבלינים חריפים, מזון מטוגן - מגבירים חום ירוק ויבש
description_hebrew: LV2: מפזר חום ירוק | LI11: מפזר חום גוף כללי

content_hebrew: מה מזון מומלץ לחסר יאנג? לחסר יאנג ממליצים מזונות מחממים ומחזקים: ג'ינג'ר, בצל, שום, כבש, עוף, קינמון, פלפל שחור, שורש ליקוריץ, שעועית אדומה, דיונון. ST36: מחזק טחול וקי | REN4: מחזק יאנג תחתון | BL23: מחזק כליות יאנג ג'ינג'ר (Zingiber officinale), כבש, קינמון (Cinnamomum cassia)
description_hebrew: ST36: מחזק טחול וקי | REN4: מחזק יאנג תחתון | BL23: מחזק כליות יאנג

content_hebrew: אילו מזונות פוגעים ביאנג? מזונות קרים וגולמיים פוגעים ביאנג: מלפפון, סלטים, אגדיר, פירות יער, מיץ תפוזים קר, גלידה, מוצרי חלב קרים, מים קרים. DU4: שער החיוניות - מחזק יאנג | REN8: מחמם תחתון דאנטיאן מזון קר - פוגע בטחול וכליות יאנג, מייצר לחות קרה
description_hebrew: DU4: שער החיוניות - מחזק יאנג | REN8: מחמם תחתון דאנטיאן

content_hebrew: מה מזון מחזק קי? מזון מחזק קי: אורז, תפוחי אדמה, גזר, כרוב, דלעת, תפוחים, תמרים, עוף, דגים לבנים, זנגביל, שורש ליקוריץ. ST36: מחזק קי וטחול | REN12: מחזק קי בטן עליונה | BL20: מחזק טחול אורז (Oryza sativa), שורש ליקוריץ (Glycyrrhiza uralensis)
description_hebrew: ST36: מחזק קי וטחול | REN12: מחזק קי בטן עליונה | BL20: מחזק טחול

content_hebrew: אילו מזונות מייצרים לחות? מזונות מייצרים לחות ופוגעים בקי טחול: חלב, גבינה, יוגורט, בננות, תפוחי אדמה לבנים, לחם לבן, סוכר לבן, מזון מעובד. SP9: מנקז לחות | ST40: מפזר לחות ופתוח חזה חלב, גבינה - מייצרים לחות קרה, חוסמים קי טחול
description_hebrew: SP9: מנקז לחות | ST40: מפזר לחות ופתוח חזה

content_hebrew: מה מזון מזין דם? מזון מזין דם: תרד, עלי מנגולד, בשר אדום במידה, ביצים, דגים, אצות, פטריות שיטאקה, תמרים אדומים, שזיפים אדומים, זרעי שומשום. BL17: נקודת דם עיקרית | SP10: מזין ומפזר דם | ST36: יוצר דם תרד (Spinacia oleracea), ביצים, תמרים (Phoenix dactylifera)
description_hebrew: BL17: נקודת דם עיקרית | SP10: מזין ומפזר דם | ST36: יוצר דם

content_hebrew: מה מזון מפזר חום? מזון מפזר חום: מלון, מלפפון, סלק, סלרי, אגדיר, מלון מים, תה ירוק, נענע, דפנה, פלפל ירוק. LI11: מפזר חום גוף | LV2: מפזר חום ירוק | ST44: מפזר חום קיבה מלון, מלפפון - קרירים ומפזרים חום, מנקזים לחות
description_hebrew: LI11: מפזר חום גוף | LV2: מפזר חום ירוק | ST44: מפזר חום קיבה

content_hebrew: אילו מזונות מגבירים חום? מזונות מגבירים חום: תבלינים חריפים, מזון מטוגן, בשר אדום, אלכוהול, קפה, שוקולד, בצל, שום, פלפל חריף. DU14: מפזר חום עליון | PC5: מפזר חום לב תבלינים חריפים - מגבירים חום יאנג

content_hebrew: מה מזון מנקז לחות? מזון מנקז לחות: שעועית אדומה, שעועית ירוקה, אורז ג'אסמין, פטריות, כרוב, סלרי, פלפל, זנגביל, פלפל שחור. SP9: מנקז לחות טחול | ST40: מנקז לחות חזה שעועית אדומה - מנקזת לחות, מחזקת טחול

content_hebrew: איך אורז עוזר לחסר קי? אורז לבן מבושל מחזק טחול וקי, קל לעיכול, מייצר נוזלים ומזין יין. אורז מלא מוסיף סיבים אבל פחות מחזק. ST36: מחזק טחול וקי | REN12: מחזק קי קיבה אורז לבן (Oryza sativa) - בסיסיתחול מזון, קל לעיכול, מחמם במידה

content_hebrew: האם חלב טוב לטחול? חלב מערבי מייצר לחות ופוגע בטחול. עדיף חלב צמחי מחומם או אורז חלב. חלב עז עשיר בשומן מחמם אבל כבד. SP6: מחזק טחול | ST36: מחזק קי חלב פרה - קר ומייצר לחות; חלב עז - מחמם יותר אך כבד

content_hebrew: מה יתרונות שורש מנה? שורש מנה מזין יין ודם, מקרר חום ירוק, מרגיע. חשוב לחסר יין כליות וכבד. KI3: יין כליות | LV8: יין כבד שורש מנה (Rehmannia glutinosa glutinosa) - מזין יין, מקרר דם

content_hebrew: Classic Chinese Medicine books Acupuncture Points The Sapir Guide to Acupuncture Point
Location and Energetic Functions Roni Sapir PhD 30 years of experience in every point © Roni Sapir Books ronisapirbooks@gmail.com

The Secrets of Chinese Medicine are in Your Hands This book provides a clear picture of the precise and effective practice of Classical Chinese Acupuncture. It is a guide for both practitioner and student alike. Inside one will find quotes from the Nei Ching Su Wen, the Yellow Emperor’s Book of Wisdom, on the use of most acupuncture

points as well as detailed information on the names of the points and their energetic qualities. The information provided on each point includes its location and needling techniques for maximum safety and efficacy. The functions, both primary and secondary, of each point make up a large portion of the book.

The reader will benefit from the variety of philosophical perspectives in this book including:  TCM, 5 Elements, and the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches. The book is crucial for every Chinese Medicine clinic and for all practitioners and students of Chinese Medicine, Tuina and Shiatsu.

Roni Sapir, PhD Roni began his journey of Chinese Medicine under the guide of Dr. Van Buren at ICOM in England. When he returned to Israel, Roni established the Ovnat College of Complementary Medicine at the Dead Sea which eventually became the East–West School of Classical

Chinese Medicine. Roni teaches the secrets of classical Chinese philosophy, the stems and branches, and practical application of the I- Ching.  Roni’s preferred style of treatment is using the stems and branches.  He implements this method using one needle of the thinnest variety.

Roni was a founder of the Israeli Association of Classical Chinese Medicine Practitioners. He played a pivotal role in drafting the bill to regulate acupuncture in the Knesset (Israeli parliament). Roni is a member of the Executive Committee of the World Acupuncture and Moxibustion Association. In the past, he has taught workshops in China
Lu 3 TIAN FU Celestial Palace 天府 Tian - heavenly
on classical techniques and been responsible for managing hospital wings there. He initiated the Zhong Fang International Red Cross Hospital and is serving as its vice president.

Over the years, Roni has spent his time advancing the field of Chinese Medicine both academically and clinically. He has established various clinics that serve the public and give his students the chance to have a specialized internship. Among these are clinics for degenerative neurological diseases such as ALS and MS, for oncology support, for

pain management, to treat infertility, and a children’s clinic. Today, Roni continues to dedicate his time and efforts to promoting the wellbeing and happiness of his patients and students. Here is what people said when Roni was voted Israel’s most influential person in Chinese Medicine:

“He has the knowledge and ability necessary to make all of his students understand Chinese Medicine.” “There is no doubt that Roni Sapir is one of the most beloved and appreciated people in this field.” “Learning with Roni changed my life.”
“As one of the founding fathers (in Israel) he has influenced this field in a persistent and concise manner.”

Introduction Man moves in the space that was formed for him and that he forms for himself. In this space, the qualities of spirit and matter coexist. It is this perspective of the world that has guided me in writing this book. This is a personal book in which the story of my life is intertwined. Indeed, my life without Classical Chinese Medicine would have taken a totally
different shape. While writing this book, the words, sentences, ideas and overall content echoed in my mind for years. They are the basis of the therapeutic and educational material, which can be a

precious tool for anybody who is passionate about helping people and guiding them towards an optimal state of health and a healthier lifestyle. This can be achieved using the same ancient teachings that have been passed down over many years from father to son and teacher to student. This book was written over 20 years. These were years of accumulating knowledge and
Bl 39 WEI YANG Bend Yang 委陽 Wei – bent

experience, years of reading and contemplating endless philosophical and academic texts. Years of enriching clinical experience throughout the world, treating patients in different cultural contexts, with a wide range of diseases and clinical manifestations. Years of rich experience teaching many disciplines of Chinese Medicine from the first training to the advanced framework.

There are many different factors that influence a clinician’s success. However, one of the most important is being able to choose the acupuncture points and to locate and needle them with skill, precision and sensitivity.  The practitioner needs an understanding of the philosophical and medical theories that are the basis of acupuncture, as well as an impeccable ability to diagnose different pathologies, in order to choose the acupuncture
points that lead to optimal clinical results.

There are a number of important schools of thought regarding the selection of acupuncture points. Each point has a name and number which express a philosophical, physical and spiritual perspective.   The broad range of perspectives includes: the body, the spirit, the emotions, astronomy, astrology, numerology, geology, the 5 elements, the I-Ching, stems and branches theory, the 9 continents and more.

When selecting points one should pay attention to their location, to which of the six divisions of the body they belong, to the Heaven Earth Man concept, and to the Three Heaters concept. In addition, the points are located on meridians which flow in a particular direction. Each meridian is an energetic extension of its related organ, is related to one of the 5 phases, and has an affinity towards motion tuned to one of the 8 trigrams. The
practitioner also must be conscious of the deep energy that activates each organ and meridian and is responsible for the organ’s function. Roni Sapir, PhD
LUNG FEI 肺 Falling leaves return to the roots - end and beginning
The three and one - concentration and distribution The Lung is the minister / ambassador / prime minister The Lung balances the Qi and regulates the
NEEDLED 0.5-1 cun FUNCTIONS 1. He - Sea point 2. Water, Horary point
body rhythm 5 elements phase: Metal Celestial stem: Sin 寅 Terrestrial Branch: Yin 寅 Trigram: Xun 巽 Wind, Penetration, Infiltration
and Tenderness. The Completion of Things is done by the Wind Six Division: Tai Yin Climate: Dampness Deep Energy: Wood
Direction: West Season: Autumn Chinese Clock: 03:00-05:00 Animal: Tiger
LU-1 ZHONG FU Central Palace 中府 Zhong - Palace

Fu - Central This is the meeting point of the Lung and Spleen. The Lung’s function of spreading Qi and the spleen’s function of forming Qi come together forming a palace/factory of Qi. LOCATION Under the lateral aspect of the clavicle, about 1 cun inferior and lateral to LU-2, on the
medial border of the deltoid muscle. 6 cun lateral to the CV, parallel to the first intercostal space. NEEDLED Perpendicularly, upwards, 0.5-1 cun FUNCTIONS

1. Mu point of Lung 2. Stabilizes and balances the Po 3. Reunion point of Tai Yin, distributes Qi to the entire body (SP forms Qi and LU disperses it), beginning point of Qi flow in the body 4. Meeting of LU/SP, jump-starts the system when LU and SP are in Qi Xu
5. Tonifies KID Yin by way of the 5 element circle 6. Sends Qi down and disperses Qi 7. Strengthens the dispersal of Wei Qi 8.  Reflex point of the lungs SECONDARY FUNCTIONS

1. Promotes the passing Qi to CO via the Metal connection 2. Regulates LU Qi and treats cough 3. Disperses body fluids 4. Clears fullness and congestion of the chest, useful for asthma 5.  Disperses Qi stuck in the Lung that is causing pain and shortness of breath

6.  With PC-6 for pain and congestion of the chest accompanied by lack of quiet, excess worrying and palpitations 7. With ST-40 for chest pain caused by accumulation of phlegm in the lungs Nei Ching When we place our fingers on PC-2, LU-1 and BL-13 the patient will feel the Qi rise. When
CV 14 JU QUE Great Gate 巨闕 Ju – big, large

we press these points (hard) this feeling will change. This is a sign of disturbance in the Qi flow. If this disturbance exists along with abdominal swelling, noisy bowels, pressure in the chest and difficulty breathing, needle these 3 points. Nei Ching-22: The upper Jiao’s Qi passes by way of LU-1. From the area of the stomach the Qi flows by way of the diaphragm, disperses in the chest, flows towards the armpit and

passes on to LU-1 and LU-2. From here the energy continues to flow to the CO meridian by way of CO-17 and CO-18. From these points it continues to flow to the tongue and then downwards by way of the esophagus returning to the stomach and intestines meeting the ST meridian. CAUTION: Contraindicated during the 9th month of pregnancy
May cause depression in women because of its connection to PC
Lu 2 YUN MEN Cloud Door 雲門 Yun - cloud

Men - gate The lungs are located in the upper jiao, which is full of heavenly water and steam (clouds/mist). Additionally they distribute fluids throughout the body (they are responsible for circulating CHI to the entire body) and function as a cloud that provides rain and nourishment to the earth. The lung - kidney connection is important for body fluid

circulation. The lungs spread dampness throughout the body and to the skin and are therefore considered the cloud gate LOCATION Inferior to the lateral border of the clavicle, in the large depression formed at the meeting of the deltoid with the pectoral muscle, 6 cun lateral to the midline
NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.3 – 1 cun FUNCTIONS

1. Activates the connection between CHI rising from kidney yang to lung's function of dispersing CHI and fluids 2. Strengthens lung's function of lowering CHI 3. Reflex point for the lungs 4. Beginning point of Wei CHI and Ying CHI flow

SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Clears fullness of the chest and stops cough 2. Strengthens the connection of cosmic CHI to the body’s CHI 3. Strengthens the lung's respiratory function CAUTIONS: Contraindicated from the beginning of the 2nd month of pregnancy
4.    Purifies wind

Fu - palace A point with a high concentration of microcosmic energy. The lung's function allows this point to be the place where microcosmic energy connects with the CHI of the entire body, influencing the deepest physical elements of the body LOCATION

On the anterior - lateral aspect of the arm, 3 cun inferior to the axilliary fold, on the radial side of the biceps brachii. or 6 cun on top of LU-5 anterior to the bone How to find it Divide the space between the axilla and the cubital crease into 3 equal spaces, hold the root of the biceps brachii separate it from the bone. The lung points are located in that space
NEEDLED Perpendicular 1 cun

FUNCTIONS 1. Heavenly star point, regulates yin and yang CHI between the upper and lower body 2. Tonifies KID yin 3. Balances between LU and TH when LU is in excess and TH is weak 4. Balances between Po and Hun

5. Promotes the passing of yin CHI from water to wood SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Strong influence on the spiritual aspects of the lung 2. Balances the TH when the TH pulse is weak and the lung pulse is full Nei Ching

“Needle this point when the patient is constantly thirsty and bleeds from the nose or mouth. Also in instances of joint inflammation, belching, hiccups or pain around the heart”. “LU-3 should be needled when the patient suddenly becomes thirsty. This condition is seen as a war between the liver and lungs and is accompanied by nosebleed and hemorrhoids.” Nei Ching -2: “The energy that is gathered at LU-3 and PC-1 comes from the middle jiao.
These 2 meridians concentrate the CHI and the middle jiao provides them with blood”. Lu 4 XIA BAI Guarding White 俠白
Xia - to protect/guard Bai - white, the color of the metal element

The color white represents the lungs. Showing a quality of protection for the lungs, preserving the meridians metal qualities LOCATION At the medial aspect of the upper arm 4 cun inferior to the auxiliary fold at the radial side of the biceps tendon (1 cun interior to LU-3)
Mellon Apple, Grapefruit Animal Protein

FUNCTIONS 1. Balances the yin and yang of LU 2. Balances the flow of CHI in the meridian. This is the point of balance between internal and external flow and the last internal point before the He- sea point where the CHI flows more externally
CAUTIONS: Contraindicated from the 5th month of pregnancy Lu 5 CHI ZE Cubit/Foot Marsh 尺澤

Chi - Chinese measurement (about 1 foot in length) Ze - swamp, place where river and sea meet This point is located in the depression 1 foot (cubit) from the hand pulse (LU-9) LOCATION In the cubital crease on the radial side of the biceps brachii tendon. Easier to feel with arm
slightly bent NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.5-1 cun FUNCTIONS 1. HE - sea point
2. Water = dispersal point 3. Reflex point 4. From LU-5 - LU-11 LU CHI flows more externally

5. Promotes the dispersal of body fluids (Jin-Ye) to the skin and tendons 6. Expels heat stemming from excess or deficiency in the lungs 7. Stem point of the water along with SI-2 SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Clears heat from the lungs and calms dry cough by dampening the lungs and throat

2. Dampens the skin and treats itching 3. Regulates rebellious lung CHI 4. With ST-40 it clears hot phlegm from the lungs CAUTIONS: Frequent needling of this point can chill and weaken the lung CHI. This can result in water accumulating in the Lungs and the formation of edema (activation of the reverse
sheng cycle). Contraindicated when patient has excess phlegm in lungs Lu 6 KONG ZUI Supreme Hole

孔最 Kong - hole Zui - the depth of the hole where excess is gathered and concentrated Zui relates to the depth of the hole and the ability of the point to store blood and CHI. Xi- cleft points are like internal storage units of CHI for the meridian. They help balance the
meridian without affecting the CHI in other meridians. LOCATION On the palmar aspect of the forearm, 7 cun proximal to LU-9 (5 cun under LU-5) on the line connecting LU-9 and LU-5 NEEDLED
Perpendicular 0.5 - 1 cun FUNCTIONS 1. XI - cleft point, regulates CHI and blood in the meridian.

2. XI - cleft point, treats all acute situations of the LU 3. Reflex point 4. Regulates rebellious lung CHI SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Special point for stopping nose bleeds (area controlled by the lung). It does so by
regulating rebellious CHI 2. For acute asthma attacks 3. Helps the circulation of blood and CHI to the hands.  Useful in treating all states of cold or heat in the hands. Lu 7
LIE QUE Broken Sequence 列缺 Lie - sequence, organization, precise location Que - partial, not complete, broken, empty, lacking

The CHI of the lung meridian is stored in LU-6. From there like a river bursting through a dam the CHI floods forward and disperses at LU-7 Lie Que, in ancient Chinese refers to lightning. The LU channel slightly diverts from its main path at LU-7 then returns at LU-8. The CHI's path here looks like lightning FUNCTIONS
1. The lou point sends a branch to CO-4 2. Master point of the CV 3. Couple point of the Yin Qiao Mai 4. Balances between left and right side of body and balances the circulation of CHI in the body

5. Crucial influence on head and neck 6. Balances between emotional, mental and physical aspects. It's outward motion releases CHI that is stuck at deep layers of the body due to emotional problems and problems expressing emotions 7. Strengthens the Wei CHI at external levels
8. When used with KID-6 on the opposite side, (opening of the CV) it is useful for regulating the flow of CHI and body fluids between the upper and lower heaters and vice versa

9. Has centrifugal motion. It raises pulses and CHI to the surface 10. Promotes the spreading and lowering of LU CHI SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Expels phlegm from the lungs 2. Expels external wind via centrifugal flow and bringing Wei CHI to outer layers
NEEDLING Perpendicular 0.3-0.5 cun FUNCTIONS 1. Shu - stream point 2. Yuan point, receives a branch from CO-6

3. Treats skin problems from external heat and stagnation of internal fluids 4. Treats chronic cough or asthma by promoting spreading and lowering lung CHI 5. With KID-6 it helps build yin via the CV 6. With CO-20 for opening the nose, stuffy nose, runny nose, sneezing and problems with the sense of smell

7. With CO-4 for clearing wind cold and promoting sweat CAUTIONS: contraindicated from the beginning of the 6th month of pregnancy Exercise caution with this point on emotionally sensitive patients Lu 8 JING QU
Across the Ditch 經渠 Jing - river, channel of stream Qu – tunnel, gutter The Su Wen states that the CHI and blood at Jing river points “move without delay”. As a

river point the CHI at this point should be flowing abundantly. The name describes the concentration and flow of CHI at this point. FUNCTIONS 1. Jing - river 2. Metal = Horary, strengthens metal and concentrates CHI
3. Concentrates CHI 4. Supports lung CHI over a long period of time 5. Strengthens the function of the Po SECONDARY FUNCTIONS

1. For controlling the sweating mechanism especially excess sweating by strengthening the metal and contracting CHI 2. For instances of excess expressed in cough, difficulty breathing and asthma caused by lack of CHI in the lungs Nei Ching
Nei Ching - 38 “In instances of cough and swelling of the face without true edema, needle the Jing river points of lung and stomach (LU-8 + ST41). CAUTIONS: contraindicated with moxa Lu 9 TAI YUAN
Great Abyss 太淵 Tai – big/large Yuan - abyss or deep-water source LU-9 represents a pit from which water is drawn. It is the Yuan point and the point of

influence on the blood vessels. Therefore the CHI here is plentiful and deep like a pit. The word Yuan indicates the connection between LU-9 and the source CHI. It represents the nature of the CHI at this point and reminds us of the point’s location in a small ditch. LOCATION At the wrist joint in the depression at the radial side of the radial artery
3. Tu - earth point, mother point 4. Hui point influencing the blood vessels (especially the arteries) 5. Sends CHI to deep layers of the body with a centripetal motion

6. Strengthens the lung’s function of lowering CHI 7. Earth point of Tai Yin with SP-3 SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Balances and stabilizes the flow of CHI throughout the body 2. Strengthens and jumpstarts the CHI resulting in stronger blood flow in the upper jiao

3. Considered the best point for CHI balancing and support in the body 4. Calms external and swollen pulses by sending CHI deep into the body (CAUTION: make sure this is not pathogenic CHI) 5. For internal and chronic deficiency 6. Concentrates the flow of blood in the arteries and veins while strengthening the

walls of the blood vessels 7. With CO-17 for Zhong CHI xu Nei Ching Su Wen - 16 “In autumn the metal element points should be needled LU-9 +LI-4”. Nei Ching-24 “When there is Heart pain and every movement the patient makes increases

the pain but there is no change in the color of the patient's face this is a sign of a LU CHI problem and one should needle LU-7 +LU-9”. Su Wen - 20: “The heaven point of the middle portion in pulses of the 9 continents”. Lu 10 YU JI
Fish Region 魚際 Yu - fish Ji - border, area The fleshy part of the hand where LU-10 is located is reminiscent of a fish's belly. “Border” is
a reference to the area between the red and white skin (or where the skins texture changes), the Yin/Yang aspect of the external body
LOCATION At the radial aspect of the first metacarpal bone,at the middle of the bone. On the line between the red and white skin. FUNCTIONS 1. Ying - spring point.

2. Huo - fire point 3. Balances between fire and metal when there is excess heat in fire (especially the heart) and cold in metal particularly the lungs 4. Accelerates circulation of CHI in LU 5. Warms the lungs
of the jaw 5. Treats inability to open the eyes 6. Influence muscular pain around the mouth

SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Dispersed it treats itching of the skin and skin problems caused by external heat 2. Dispersed it treats throat pain and can be bled mostly for disease caused by external pathogenic wind heat accompanied by hoarse throat, loss of voice Nei Ching

Nei Ching - 24: “When there is a problem with the Lungs, needle the YING (spring) point of the LU and the stream point of the Kidney (KID-3). This is because of their close relationship by way of the physiology of the TH”. SU WEN - 52: “If LU-10 is needled incorrectly or too many times, the energetic balance will be interrupted and form swelling”.
CAUTION Excess usage can dry up the lungs. Some say it should not be tonified more than 5 times over the course of a patient’s life. Forbidden with moxa.
Lu 11 SHAO SHANG Young/Lesser Merchant 少商 Shao - small, young, little

Shang - the 5th tone on the Chinese musical scale The note “Shang” is related to metal and therefor the lungs. LU-11 situated on a yin meridian, is considered “lesser shang”, small because the 5 notes are divided into big and small. The Yin aspect of each note is lesser. Jing well points have a polarity of yin/yang. Here the yin of the lung transforms into the yang of the colon.
LOCATION At the radial side of the thumb, 0.1 cun proximal and lateral the corner of the nail. NEEDLED Transverse - oblique, 0.1 cun (causes local pain), used in bleeding FUNCTIONS
1. Jing - well point 2. Mu - wood point 3. Exit of the Lu TMM 4. Influences the LU divergent meridian 5. Point of polar change from yin to yang. The most yang point on the meridian
6. Strengthens dispersal of LU CHI 7. Strengthens flow of Wei CHI in meridian 8. Deep energy point of the lung (wood) SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Promotes sweat and clears external pathogens

2. Clears heat from the LU and cleans hot wind by strengthening the function and flow of Wei CHI 3. Sends CHI to the LU meridian 4. In dispersal for psychotic attacks caused by excess yang-wood severing the concentration of the Po

5. Dispersed and bled to clear heat causing severe throat pain and cough 6. According to a number of sources needled for cough, throat and neck pain, acute wind attack also congestion of fluid in the spine and heart stroke 7. Classic point for treating noises in the ears caused by deficiency of prenatal CHI 8. For high blood pressure

9. For epilepsy and for mental breakdown Nei Ching Nei Ching “The ear is a place where ancestral CHI is unified. When the stomach is empty the ancestral meridians are also empty, the CHI will flow to the bottom of the body causing pressure, tonify LU-11”.

Nei Ching-23: “Needle when there is fever in order to promote sweat. If in 7-8 days the radial pulse of the right hand deteriorates and pounds very hard, and the patient has signs of shortness of breath, heaviness or difficulty breathing needle LU-11 which automatically promotes sweat”. CAUTIONS: contraindicated with moxa
Large Intestine / COLON Da Chang 大腸 Stimulation and guidance for direction, direction and definition
Bride and transfer The colon is responsible for the transformation of all the murk. All waste products pass through this site and from there the form changes.
5 elements phase: Metal Celestial stem: Geng 庚 Terrestrial Branch: Mao 卯 Trigram: Zhen 震 Six Division: Yang Ming
Climate: Dryness Deep Energy: Wood Direction: West Season: Autumn Chinese Clock: 05:00-07:00
Animal: Rabbit
Co 1 SHANG YANG Merchant of Yang 商陽 Shang - merchant, 5th note on Chinese musical scale

Yang - yang energy Shang is the sound related to the metal element. LU-11 and CO-1 are the only points on the metal meridians that have a connection to Shang. From here we learn that these point are effective in treating problems of the throat, the place where the 5 tones are formed. These points influence the vocal chords and the sounds that they make. CO-1 treats higher tones
St 5 DA YING Big Welcome 大迎 Da – big
and LU-11 treats lower ones. Likewise as this point is the metal point of the Colon it has the ability to concentrate yang CHI at its peak LOCATION
At the radial aspect of the index finger, 0.1 cun proximal to the tip of the fingernail NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.2 - 0.3 cun or 15° towards the hand, 2 – 3 mm Used in bleeding FUNCTIONS
1. Jing - well point 2. Metal - Horary point 3. Exit of CO TMM 4. Influences CO divergent meridians 5. Receives CHI from LU
6. Metal point of Yang Ming with ST-45 7. Stem point of metal with LIV-4 SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Clears internal hot wind 2. Expels external wind

3. Opens blockages in the colon meridian 4. For facial neuralgia caused by blockage of the CO TMM 5. Used with LU-11 for tonsillitis by clearing heat from the throat Nei Ching Su Wen -63: “The points CO-1 + LU-11 are used for intermittent deafness”.

Su Wen -63: “The points CO-1 +LU-11 are used for Asthma, heaviness in the chest and heat sensation in the chest”. Su Wen -62: “The points LU-7+CO-1 are used for clearing internal heat that causes a hot disease”. CAUTIONS: contraindicated with moxa.
Co 2 ER JIAN Second Space

二間 Er - 2 or second Jian - portion, space, hole Er Jian is the second point on the meridian. It is also the distal point to the metacarpal phalangeal joint. The points name is a reminder of its location

LOCATION With a lightly formed fist, it is located on the radial side of the index finger in the depression distal to the 2nd metacarpal phalangeal joint, on the line separating the red and white skin. NEEDLED Diagonal in the direction of the meridians flow, 0.3 cun
FUNCTIONS 1. Ying –   Spring point 2. Water - Child point SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. As a water point it clears heat especially internal heat in the intestines
NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.5-1 cun FUNCTIONS 1. Window of sky 2. Upper meeting of LU and CO divergent

2. Sends fluids to the intestines, good for constipation and dry feces 3. For tooth pain from heat which causes inflammation of the gums and teeth (gums are controlled by Yang Ming, upper gums by the ST and the Lower gums by the CO) CAUTIONS: contraindicated beginning in the 8th month of pregnancy Co 3
SAN JIAN Third Space
三間 San - 3, 3rd Jian - hole, space, part San Jian is the 3rd point on the meridian LOCATION

When the hand is held in a relaxed fist, the point is found on the radial side, in the proximal depression inferior to the 2nd metacarpal head, where the skin’s texture changes. NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.3 cun FUNCTIONS
1. Shu – stream point 2. Wood point 3. Balances between wood and metal. Calms excess wood energy while increases control over wood 4. Deep energy point of the Colon (wood)

SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Treats joint problems, BI - Syndrome by increasing circulation of CHI 2. For anger stuck in the liver, balances metal and wood Nei Ching Su Wen -60: “When one is suffering from cold or hot sensations caused by food stagnation,
it should be treated by moxa in order to open the stagnation/blockage. If this treatment fails, needle this point”. Co 4 HE GU Joining of the Valleys
合谷 He - to put together, to meet, unity Gu - valley He Gu is a depression reminiscent of a valley found at the meeting of the 1st and 2nd metacarpal bones

He Gu is the name of a mountain; the same landscape is seen on the muscle that rises up when the thumb and index finger are put together LOCATION Between the 1st and 2nd metacarpal bones at the middle of the 2nd metacarpal bone Additional location: at the peak of the muscle that protrudes when the thumb and index
finger are squeezed together - for influence on the face and gums Additional location: distal to the base of the 1st and 2nd metacarpal bones - a variety of influences NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.5-1 cun
St 20 CHENG MAN Receiving Fullness 承满 Cheng – to receive, support

FUNCTIONS. 1.Yuan point receives branch from LU-7 2. Strong influence on body's general yang. Strengthens and builds circulation of Wei CHI. 3. Influences the colon TMM 4. Command point for face and mouth

SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Clears hot and cold wind 2. For headache, pain of the intestines and pain from BI - syndrome 3. Strengthens CHI throughout the body especially when used with ST-36 4. Opens the flow of CHI in the meridians

5. Bilateral needling with LIV-3 the four gates treatment will: accelerate the body's CHI which will open stagnation, open the body’s internal gates thus calming the soul. Useful for constipation from stagnation of CHI and blood with fecal accumulation and calms liver fire

6. With ST-44 for toothache. CO - 4 is needled on the opposite side of the pain because the meridian flows to the opposite side of the body around the mouth and ST-44 is needled on the side of the pain. 7. With KID-7 for regulating sweat Nei Ching

Su Wen - CH-20: “Earth point of the middle jiao according to the pulses of the 9 continents”. Su Wen  -16: “In the Autumn needle CO-4 +LU-9”. Ling Shu -213: “When there are holes in the teeth causing pain in the lower jaw needle CO- 4”. CAUTION
Contraindicated in pregnancy Frequent dispersal of this point can lead to deafness and knee pain Co 5 YANG XI Valley of Yang
陽谿 Yang – yang, that which completes yin Xi - stream, valley Yang Xi is located on the yang aspect of the hand between 2 tendons that function as the walls of the valley.

LOCATION When the thumb is spread open, the point is located between the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus muscle and the extensor pollicis brevis in the “snuff box” NEEDLED:  perpendicular 0.3-0.5 cun FUNCTIONS
1. Jing -  river point 2. Fire point 3. Activates the CO TMM SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Strong influence on the Wei CHI, clears external pathogens
With the hand raised a depression is formed at this point. This is a place easily penetrated by external wind

2. Clears wind 3. Treats pain from blockage in the TMM 4. Treats local problems especially BI - syndrome of the wrist 5. Dispersed, brings down fire from the colon and anus 6. Dispersed for pathogenic heat along the meridian including inflammation of gums
7. Dispersed for chilling external heat causing skin problems, itching, rashes and burning of the skin Co 6 PIAN LI Inclined Passage
偏歴 Pian - to lean to one side Li - to pass through, walk, branch Pian Li is a reference to the deep branch connecting the colon meridian with the lung meridian
LOCATION On the line connecting CO5 - CO11,3 cun proximal to the wrist joint NEEDLED Diagonal 0.5-1 cun FUNCTIONS

1. Lou point, sends branch to LU-9 2. Sends CHI downwards 3. Useful when there is excess CHI in the colon, sends CHI to the LU 4. Gives the lungs wood CHI 5. With LU-7 (both Lou point) moves the metal element and releases blockages
SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. With SI7, 8 strengthen the triple heater internal duct thus strengthening kidney yin. 2. With LU-9 balances metal Co 7 WEN LIU
Warm Current

温溜 Wen - warming, to purify something hot due to accumulation Liu – to flow, slip, surf The Yang Ming has plentiful CHI and blood. The name is a reference to the concentration of CHI and blood in this point. The concentration of CHI and blood here is hot and plentiful it
effortlessly flows and spreads out. LOCATION On the line connecting CO-5 -CO-11, 5 cun above the wrist. NEEDLED Diagonal 0.5-1 cun, in the direction of the meridian
ENERGETIC FUNCTIONS 1. XI - cleft point, regulates CHI and blood in the meridian SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. For acute pain expressed along the colon meridian Co 8
XIA LIAN Inferior Region
下廉 Xia - relatively low, under Lian - mountain range The name is a reference to the point’s location at the (mountain range) of the arm, under the elbow below CO-9

LOCATION 8 cun proximal to CO-5 on the line connecting CO-5 - CO-11 NEEDLED Diagonal in the direction of the meridians flow 0.5-1 cun (Perpendicular or diagonal at a 45-degree angle in the direction of the meridians flow)

Co 9 SHANG LIAN Upper Region
上廉 Shang - relatively high, on top of Lian - Mountain range Shang Lian is located on top of  Xia Lian (CO-8) on the same “mountain range” LOCATION

On the line connecting CO-5-CO11, 9 cun proximal to CO-5. 1 cun on top of CO-8, 3 cun under CO-11 NEEDLED Diagonal in the direction of the meridians flow 0.5-1 cun Perpendicular or diagonal 45 degrees in the direction of the meridian

Co 10 SHOU SAN LI Arm Three Li
手三里 Shou - arm, limb, upper San - 3 Li - a measurement, approximately 1/3 of a mile Shou San Li is related to Zu San Li (ST-36). Both of them are on the Yang Ming and are

located under the elbow In classical Chinese the note “LI” means to regulate or to activate, showing us this points ability to balance all 3 heaters LOCATION On the line connecting CO-5 - CO-11 10 cun above the wrist

3. With ST-36 it strengthens the body's overall CHI and the digestive system Co 11 QU CHI
Pool At The Bend 曲池 Qu - bent, crooked, Chi - pool, lake, dam Describing the Chi being poured into the sea point like water being poured into a pool

LOCATION With the elbow folded, it is located in the depression at the lateral border of the cubital crease, half- way between LU5 and the lateral epicondyle of the humerus NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.5-1 cun

5. Balances the pulses of water and earth, strengthens the metal and by doing so increases  control over wood SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Calms the body by cooling it down 2. Regulates blood via the connection with the earth element and Yang Ming

3. For skin problems stemming from heat in the blood or blood deficiency 4. With BL-40 for skin problems from heat in the blood (blood cooling points) 5. For constipation, activates intestines and supports earth element Co 12 ZHOU LIAO
Elbow Bone 肘髎 Zhou - elbow Liao - bone, hole, deep hole/indentation in a bone Zhou Liao is the notch in the bone above the elbow where the point is located

Small Intestine Xiao Chang 小腸 Turn iron into gold – priorities- building man The small intestine receives the food that is

FUNCTIONS 1. Treats local elbow pain 2. Opens blockages in the CO meridian, good for pain between the elbow and shoulder SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. For tennis elbow when the main problem is along the Colon meridian
CO 13 SHOU WU LI
Arm Five Li 手五里 Shou - hand, arm, upper limb Wu - 5 Li - townsquare, to dwell, a measurement of 1/3 of a mile

This point is located about 5 cun above the elbow and 5 inches under Tian Fu celestial palace (LU-3). Its name is a reference to its location This is the Xi - Cleft point of the 5 zang organs where CHI from all 5 elements meets LOCATION Superior to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus, 3 cun proximal to CO-11 on the line
connecting CO-11 - CO-15 NEEDLED Perpendicular in the direction of the meridians flow 0.5-1 cun FUNCTIONS 1. Balances the body by dispersing 5 element CHI
2. Disperses CHI of the yin organs SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. May cause changes in the patient’s personality because it influences all of the body's yin Nei Ching

Su Wen - 3: “The point CO-13 disperses all of the yin organs. It should either never be needled or not needled more than 5 times in the patient lifetime”. CAUTION: needling is forbidden it can cause dispersal of the 5 Zang and change in personality. Co 14
BI NAO Upper Arm 臂臑 Bi - arm Nao - upper
A reference to the point’s location LOCATION About 7 cun proximal to CO-11 on the line connecting CO11-CO-15 at the place where the meridian crosses the border of the deltoid muscle NEEDLED
Perpendicular 0.5-1 cun FUNCTIONS 1. Cleans and purifies the meridian from blockages SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. For eye and shoulder problems

JIAN YU shoulder bone 肩髃 Jian - shoulder Yu - corner, clavicula

The point’s name describes its location at the meeting of the humerus and acromion LOCATION When the arm is raised parallel to the ground 2 notches are formed. The point is located in the anterior notch at the anterior - inferior border of the acromion-clavicula How to find it

Hold both sides of the acromion and fall into the connecting point between the 2 bones the point is located at the most anterior of the 2 notches NEEDLED Perpendicular 1-1.5 cun when the hand is raised in the direction of HT-1 FUNCTIONS
1. Meeting with SI 2. Meeting with Yang Qiao Mai 3. Exit of colon divergent 4. Strengthens the heart and chest (especially when needled towards HT1) 5. Expels internal wind used for treating stroke

6. Crucial for treating the shoulders SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. When needled towards HT-1 it strengthens the pulses of the fire element 2. Treats pain (mostly of the shoulders) 3. Strengthens the circulation of CHI in the meridians
4. Benefits the tendons of the shoulder, local point for frozen shoulder CAUTIONS Exercise caution with patients with heart conditions because this point can cause too much
yang CHI to penetrate the heart. Co 16
JU GU Large Bone 巨骨 Ju - big, long, large Gu - bone

Ju Gu is the ancient name for the Clavicle This points name describes the bulge at the clavicle scapula joint LOCATION In the notch medial to the meeting of the acromion of the clavicle with the spine of scapula NEEDLED

Perpendicular and slightly diagonally outward, 1 cun in order not to damage the Lung’s Apex FUNCTIONS 1. Meeting point with the YANG QIAO MAI 2. Concentrates and lowers excess yang CHI from upper body, brings it down into the yin 3. Brings CHI down
SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Opens local blockages in the shoulder 2. Calms rising rebellious CHI 3. Strengthens lung CHI 4. Benefits the joints
4. Treats constipation 5. Palpation for diagnosing ovarian problems i.e. heat/cold. Treats infertility from deficient blood and YE in the womb

5. With CO-15 to treat shoulder problems 6.  Opens the chest, calms rebellious LU CHI, cough, asthma and shortness of breath 7.   Opens stagnations and moves blood and CHI in the chest 8.   From CO-16 the CHI flows to GV-14 - ST-12
Co 17 TIAN DING Celestial Vessel 天鼎 Tian – pre - heaven, celestial, divine, natural, upper portion of the body

Ding - ancient Chinese cooking vessel with 2 handles that are similar to ears supported by a tripod, or an ancient Chinese vessel used for sacrifices This points name is a metaphor for the neck, which supports the head like a tripod supporting a pot. This “pot” is highly valuable because it contains the head, which is “the storage place of the original spirit”. The brain is a combination of Jing and Shen.
LOCATION At the lateral side of the neck, at the posterior border of the SCM, about 1cun inferior to CO-18 NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.1-1 cun

FUNCTIONS 1. Strengthens the motion of the neck muscle 2. Supports the flow of CHI between head and chest by way of the neck 3. Preserves the free flow of CHI between the head and neck 4. Stores essences after CO-16, before the meridian rises to the head
SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Sends a branch to the tongue, influencing the throat, for hoarseness, rebellious CHI, hiccups and swelling of the local lymph nodes
Co 18 FU TU Support and Rush 扶突 Fu - to help, to assist, support

Tu - sudden, bulge, radiate Fu Tu supports the head, located at the area marked by the largest bulge in the body, the thyroid cartilage. Additionally this point promotes the departure of blood and CHI upwards to support the head Not used in patients with eye problems because it speeds up the flow of CHI to the eyes and

can cause the patient to experience a sudden blinding flash of light. This is why the word “tu” - sudden is used to describe it. LOCATION At the line even with the bulge of the pharyngeal prominence on the body line, between the anterior and superior borders of the SCM, between both of the SCM heads

3. Sends CHI and blood to the head 4. Strengthens the metal element (minerals etc) and sends them to the head SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. Benefits the throat, stops cough 2. Melts down lumps and disperses phlegm
3. Sends a branch to the tongue 4. Locally, it treats tonsillitis, mumps, diseases of the throat and problems affecting the voice chords
CAUTION Do not needle on patients with eye problems
Co 19 HE LIAO Grain Bone 禾髎 He - alcove, hole

Liao - grain, rice, corn He Liao is located in the depression of the bone that is the size of a grain, between the teeth and gums LOCATION Under the lateral borders of the nostril, on the same line as GV-26

Co 20 YING XIANG Welcome Fragrance 迎香 Ying - blessed, to meet, to receive

Xiang - smell, the aroma associated with earth This point’s name tells us that CO-20 is the place where the stomach meridian meets the colon meridian. It is the meeting of aromas; this includes the 5 fragrances according to the 5 elements, most significantly the aroma of Earth. LOCATION
Lateral to the widest part of the nostrils, halfway between the ala nasal and naso labial groove NEEDLED Perpendicular 0.1-0.5 cun FUNCTIONS

1. Meeting with ST 2. Sends a branch to ST1 - BL1 closing the Yang Ming 3. Clears wind heat from the lungs 4. Disperses external wind (generally hot) that penetrated the lungs accompanied by sneezing and stuffy nose

Representing the 4 white areas surrounding the Iris above, below and to the sides This point can whiten the 4 sides of the sclara when they are red LOCATION In the notch in the infra orbital foramen directly under the center of the pupil at the lower portion of the Sphynoid

5. Pushes yang - thunder that explodes and bursts forth from within the frozen yin SECONDARY FUNCTIONS 1. For sinusitis (inflammation, hot phlegm) opens the passages blocked with mucus 2. Excellent for clearing clogged nose 3. For problems with the sense of smell, nose bleeding , allergies, hot phlegm in the

CHENG QI Tear Container 承泣 Cheng– to contain, hold Qi – tears

St 8 TOU WEI Head Corner 頭維 Tou – head

(resulting in a heavy sensation of the head) 7. Crucial for treating frontal headaches of the Yang Ming CAUTIONS: contraindicated with moxa

division”. Si 4 WAN GU Wrist Bone 腕骨

Ht 1 JI QUAN Extreme Fountain 極泉 Ji - high, extreme

Quan - fountain The heart organ rules the entire body. Its function is the most important. Therefore “ji”, extreme/high is used to describe the first point on its meridian. “Ji” is not reminding us of the point’s height but of its utmost importance as the first point on the emperor’s meridian. It flows cosmic CHI throughout the body. As the “beginning” point of the SHEN’s flow it is
Perpendicular 0.5 cun FUNCTIONS 1. Lou point sends a branch to SI-4 2. Calms the SHEN 3. Regulates HT fire

one of the most physically hidden points. “Fountain” shows us how the point circulates the spirit SHEN throughout the body. LOCATION With the arm raised, this point is located in the center of the armpit, at the deepest point in the axilla, at the medial aspect of the axillary artery
NEEDLED Perpendicular 1 – 1.5 cun or diagonal in the direction of the meridian

5. Supports the element of fire and warms it. SECONDARY FUNCTIONS Nourishes SP fire by way of the sheng cycle For people with communication difficulties For pain from frozen shoulder (local cold + cold in SP)

If this is not the case, needle and bleed the unifying point of the meridians, which is located under the tongue. (These points are “zin zin” and “yee yee” they are the meeting points of KID CHI

with the tongue). If the patient does not recover immediately, needle and bleed BL40. BL61. If the disease begins with pain of the spine and pain near the kidneys, needle and bleed BL40.” Su Wen – 41: “When the tai yang meridians are attacked the patient will suffer from pain

Attachments The attachments are a vital part of the book. it contain a lot of information for the clarity and the success of the treatments Basic rules and contraindications for acupuncture In the following instances one should exercise caution before deciding to use

acupuncture and be meticulous in choosing acupuncture points. 1. In cases of exhaustion and fatigue it is preferable to support the patient with moxa on St36 and/or Cv6 2.  If the patient has been fasting there is risk of fainting. It is preferable to eat 30 minutes before receiving acupuncture after a prolonged fast.

3. Do not needle after a heavy meal or if the patient feels stuffed. 4. Exercise caution in needling when the patient is experiencing an extreme emotional state, e.g. joy or sadness. Needling in these circumstances may result in reverse flow of CHI. 5. Immediately after conception, acupuncture should only be done by a
doctor who understands the process of pregnancy from conception

through birth and the unique changes in the patterns of CHI flow which take place during this process. 6. 6. Do not needle in instances where there is dissonance between the complexion and the pulse in terms of pattern diagnostics. This shows an energetic imbalance. Breathing techniques should be used to regain

balance before using acupuncture. 7. When the weather does not support the treatment, e.g. in extremely stormy weather avoid strong needle stimulation especially when treating acute pathologies. In extreme heat, do not use moxa. 8. When the time of the treatment does not support the treatment, e.g.
during the evening and night time avoid strong needle stimulation unless the pathology is strong and acute.

PREGNANCY The process of pregnancy is one of upmost importance. The physician must fully understand and support this physiologic process in a very precise manner. The body of a pregnant woman is constantly working to nourish the fetus and sustain the pregnancy. We must have these

objectives in mind when treating a pregnant woman. One of the most important things to remember is the energetic balance in her body is markedly different from a state of non-pregnancy. Consequently, there are acupuncture points which would be dangerous to manipulate or cause to return to their prior state of function (as they

were before pregnancy).  The reasons for this include the points’ function, the direction in which they send energy, their meeting/influence on other points and the points’ location on the body. Examples 1. CO4 is contraindicated throughout pregnancy. This is due to its
כל נקודות ה– BL –Moxa is forbidden on the thhypergastric area after the 6 month   LIV-4,  SP-2,  REN-3,  REN- 4,  REN-5,  REN-6

strong yang quality which can cause contractions. For this same reason, it is also a very effective point during labor. 2. SP6 is contraindicated for the entire pregnancy because it is responsible for balancing the subtle environmental changes in the womb e.g. dampness and heat. Needling may disrupt this delicate

3. Ren6 is contraindicated because of its location 4. BL23 and DU4 are both contraindicated because of their locations. Also, DU4 has a strong energetic effect on the kidneys and BL23 has a strong connection with the DAI MAI, both systems should be used cautiously during pregnancy.

Additional Cautions 1. A pregnant woman who is very weak should not be needled. 2. Exercise extreme caution in treatment if the patient has a history of miscarriages 3. Do not needle a pregnant woman experiencing extreme emotional
tension resulting in extreme anger, sadness or anxiety. 4. Do not needle a pregnant woman suffering extreme acute pain in the upper or lower abdomen.

Points Forbidden with Moxa There are a couple of acupuncture points that per the classics, are contraindicated with moxa. The main reason for this is their proximity to vital blood vessels. The heat from moxa on these points can cause changes to the bodies of these vessels as well as

to the flow of blood inside of them. REN-15, SP-9, ST-38, GB-1, ST-9, LU-8 DU-15, DU-16, BL-10, GB-15, TH-23, BL-1, CO-20, Per the Nan Jing the use of the following points is forbidden with moxa. LU- 1,2,3,4,5,8

5 Elements Chinese medicine divides the world of phenomenon into 5 elements, or per some translations “5 phases��. Each element has its own unique characteristics be they physical or metaphysical. The elements have a flow and rhythm unique to each one through which they are manifested in the world. Nonphysical
Millet Rice Beans Fruit Apple Cherry, Strawberry Date, Olive Pecan,

associations of the organs include; direction and climate which are ideas associated with heaven.  When speaking of the elements, physical concepts include; taste, the organs themselves, tissue and bodily functions. The elements do not exist as individual entities. They are mutually involved in a closed-circuit relationship where one’s activity influences and is

influenced by the activity (or lack thereof) of another. One of the most crucial relationships to be aware of amongst the elements is that of generating and controlling. Understand how the elements interact with each other, gives us a more complete understanding of the person in our care, the signs with which he is presenting and what elements are out of balance.

While we consider all the elements when making a diagnosis, it is important to focus on the ones that are dominant and perhaps overcontrolling others. Over control can happen when an element is in a state of excess. Thus, it will seek to control an element that is weak. This will lead to further weakening of the controlled element.

The same system of control and generating that exists on the micro level (in living organisms), exists on the macro level (in the universe at large). Their relationship’s and resulting effects can be observed in the climate, seasons, hourly etc. This perspective lays the groundwork for diagnosis and treatment in
Chinese Medicine. Also, the food, sounds and emotions that are related to each element give us a deeper understanding of pathology as well as tools for treatment.

details Memory Transport/Antique points There are 60 acupuncture points that are considered crucial energetic points on the body. These points allow us to balance the meridians in a unique
manner per the energy that is needed. On the arm meridians, these points are located between the elbows and fingers. On the leg meridians, they are between the knees and toes.

Each of the 12 primary meridians has points labeled; Jing-well, Ying- spring, Shu-stream, Jig-river and He-sea. These points have a direct connection to the 5 phases and the nourishing (sheng) cycle that is constantly at play. On the yin meridians, the first of these points is always associated with the wood element. On the yang meridians, the first will always be a metal point.
TMM Meeting points Points Area of meeting Ren 3 Ren 4 3 leg yin TMM SI18 ST12 3 yang hand TMM Ren17 GB22 GB23 3 yin hand TMM

With an understanding of 5 element theory, one can use these points in a variety of ways to balance and influence the 5 elements in the body. 1. Mother point – This is the point associated with the element that nourishes/births the element of the relevant meridian i.e. LU9 & CO11 are both earth points on metal meridians. These will influence the

process of earth nourishing metal. 2. Child point – This is the point associated with the element that is nourished by the relevant meridian. They are also called “dispersal” points because their energetic flow is in the opposite direction of the nourishing cycle i.e. LU5 & CO2 are both water points on metal

meridians and thus nourish the metal element with water energy. One should exercise caution when using these points as they cause energy to flow in the opposite direction than its normal coursing. 3. Horary points – Theses are points associated with the element that the relevant meridian belongs to. LU8 and CO1 are metal points on metal

meridians. These are generally used for two purposes; to strengthen the characteristic of an element and its influence on the body. Or, during treatments done at the time that the organ/meridian is dominant to increase that systems functionality even more. An example being using LU8 between 3-5 AM to increase the lungs’ metal energy.

8 EXTRAORDINARY MERIDIANS The 8 extraordinary meridians are opened by using both a “master” and “couple” point. To allow for a good treatment one must follow a few basic rules 1. Needle the master point first and the couple point second.

2. Master points are needled on the left side on men and on the right for women. 3. Couple points are needled on the right side for men and the left for women. 4. When taking needles out, the couple point is removed first and the
master point second. 5. During a treatment where and extraordinary meridian is opened, the use of other points on that meridian is contraindicated (see intro to extraordinary points). Yang
Meridians ST SI TH GB BL CO Metal 45 1 1 44 67 1 Water 44 2 2 43 66 2 Wood 43 3 3 41 65 3

6. The duration of needle retention is calculated per the time of day and what organ is dominant at the time of treatment. The practitioner should wait to feel 3 peaks in the pulse of the dominant organ, upon feeling the 3rd, needles are removed e.g. at noon one should wait to feel 3 peaks in the heart pulse. After the 3rd peak is felt, remove the needles
in the correct order. DU REN CHONG DAI YIN WEI YIN QIAO YANG WEI YANG QIAO

influence Xi – cleft points There is a total of 16 Xi-cleft points on the body. 12 of them belong to the primary meridians and 4 to the 8 extraordinary meridians. “Xi” is used to describe a pool where energy from the meridian accumulates. These points

can be used in the following situations. 1. When we want to immediately increase and intensify the flow of energy in a meridian by tapping into the meridians internal reserves and not a deeper place of storage. 2. Acute instances requiring immediate change in energy.

3. Adjusting the direction of flow in the meridian. Xi – cleft points can also be used as reflex points. Palpation of these points can provide us with information regarding the meridians state of excess or deficiency. In deficiency, the point will feel sunken, soft, cold and lacking tension. In a state of excess, they will feel hard, protruding, hot, painful, tense
and give exaggerated resistance. LU- 6 LU CO-7 CO ST34 ST SP-8 SP

KID-9 YIN WEI Mu Points There are 12 Mu points found on the body, one for each organ. These points have a yin nature and therefore influence the physical aspect of their associated organs. Another sign of these being yin in nature

is their location. All of them are found on the anterior aspect of the body (chest, upper and lower abdomen). They are crucial points to influence the body’s function. The Mu points are used to influence the building of yin material of their associated organ. They are not used to influence the energetic aspect of organs. Doing so, is a task
reserved for the Shu points. Additionally, Mu points are reflex points of their organs. Mu points LU- 1 LU REN- 17 PC

these points are used to treat warm disease. Additionally, they can be used to treat the system which they represent. Influential/8 meeting points (BA HUI) LIV13 Zang REN12 FU

GB13  3 yang hand TMM REN 2  GB + LIV TMM These points are important in understanding the physiology of the Tendo Muscular Meridians. The TMM, via these points, can stop a pathogen which has made its way into the body from further
penetrating. We can tonify the defensive CHI at these areas using the TMM meeting points.
DIVERGENT MEETING and EXIT POINTS Exit Lower Meeting Upper Meeting BL40 KID10  BL40 BL10 SI8 HT1 btwn HT1 + GB22 BL1 TH10 PC1 unlisted TH16
ST34 SP10 ST30 BL1 CO15 LU3 CO18 GB30 LIV5 REN2 GB1 The divergent meridians serve as a highway taking CHI from the yin meridians to the head. Since the yin meridians do not reach the head

and brain, they divert from their main pathways and meet divergent pathways of the yang meridians. It is through these passages that yin CHI arrives at the head and brain. It is important to remember the pathways of the divergents so that we can follow the progression of CHI flow between the left and right side of the body.

Shokanten points are meeting points of the 6 warps. The above chart shows the 6 warps and their Shokanten points. These points are used when the practitioner wishes to do the following: 1. Supporting one of the 6 warps 2. Influencing the expression of an internal climate associated with one of

the 6 warps e.g. cold water is influenced by Kid12. It will support the Tai Yang which expresses a climate of cold. 3. Balancing the 9 continents When using Shokanten points one should consider all the above principals particularly the first 2.

These points can be used to draw upon the CHI of the meridians meeting there, for local or broader systemic energetic influences. Important Reminder: TH8 is a forbidden point in acupuncture. It can be manipulated by way of massage or moxa.

The Clock The use of opposites on the Chinese clock is known as “mid-day -mid night”. This is a fundamental law giving us insight to the energetic changes which occur throughout the day.  This principle is rooted in seeing the dynamic balance in cycles of energy. The 24-hour day is divided in to 12 hours of yang

dominance (12:00-00:00) and 12 hours of yin dominance (00:00-12:00). Bearing in mind the principle of polarity of yin and yang, the Chinese clock shows us that when an organ is at its energetic peak, another organ (its clock opposite) is experiencing an energetic ebb e.g. at 12:00 pm the heart is at its peak. At the same time gall bladder is experiencing its ebb. This reciprocal

waxing and waning of yin and yang is constantly taking place. Clinically this is a very important principle to consider, in that if we tonify an organ we also suppress its clock opposite. During a treatment, one must consider the system being needled and the system that is dominant at the time of the treatment as well as the opposites of each. The reason for this is that if we support an organ
in treatment, we can potentially weaken (by suppressing) its clock opposite.

In Chinese Medicine the skill of pulse diagnosis is one that the practitioner will hone for the rest of his life. It is the most trustworthy diagnostic tool for the experienced practitioner. At the most basic level of pulse diagnoses, one can differentiate and understand the states of the 3 Jiao and the Zang and Fu organs. As one acquires more skill, the pulses of the 8 extraordinary meridians

will begin to be felt more clearly. When the 8 extraordinary are more clear, the practitioner will be able to diagnose disruption in the function of each organ in the body per the 3 all-encompassing aspects of life:  spirit, physical function of each organ and the amount and potential of prenatal Jing available. The pulses introduced here lay the groundwork for the basic initial pulse
diagnoses used by practitioners of Classical Chinese Medicine. Classical Pulses Location Cosmology  Left Hand  Right Hand Distal Heaven SI/HT LU/CO Medial Earth GB/LIV SP/ST

Ba Gua The Ba Gua form the underlying philosophy of the book of changes (the I Ching). The central concept of the Ba Gua express’s the interactions   between the energies of heaven and earth and all that exists between them. Every interaction of the Ba Gua results in the actualization of a new phenomenon.

This new phenomenon is a direct result of the specific qualities and dynamic relationship of the Ba Gua that brought it into being. The Ba Gua are geometric structures made up of 8 trigrams. Each trigram describes an interaction between yang (represented by a full line) and yin (represented by a broken line). The relationships between the trigrams
listed below help us gain perspective on process of creation and the dynamic balancing that is constantly occurring in the universe.

The use of what I call I-Ching acupuncture, requires impeccable skill which is acquired through understanding the trigrams, 5 elements, 5 phases, the 4 seasons, the dynamic relationships between organs and meridians, understanding what is felt in the pulse, and the ability to synchronize these things. There is no doubt that without the I – Ching, Chinese Medicine would

not have developed to the state that it is in today. I firmly believe that without the understanding of the trigrams, ones understanding of Chinese Medicine will be incomplete. Energetic Concept Trigram Organ/Meridian trickling/internalization Sun LU
Penetrate, thunder, trembling Chen Colon Fear, lacking certainty  Kan  ST Fire, radiating Li SP
Ritual bath, water in the endless dessert, Tui HT Mountain, yang at the peak of yin, building of
life’s most basic matter Ken SI Peak of formation and distribution, maximum energy in all 3 Jiao
Absorption, to both contain and give what is absorbed from heaven Kun KID
Minister of the heart, the heart’s physical distribution (blood) and its position as emperor Tui PC
Mountain, meditation, awareness of all directions, connecting to the external Ken TH
Ultimate penetrating force Chien GB Fullness of yin and its giving the base of life
Kun LIV Maximum yin, mother Kun Ren Maximum yang, father Chien Du

Deep Energy Each organ in the body has a deep energy which activates and preserves the dynamic balance of that organ and thus does so for the entire body. For example, the expanding and contracting of the lungs and large intestine require the motion of the wood element. Without this wood energy, the

physiological process of breathing and peristalsis would not be possible. Therefore, when using a meridian one must consider it’s deep energy which influences the body as a unit. If a person is experiencing mental and energetic stagnation, we would not use points on the stomach meridian. Doing so may intensify the innate heaviness of the earth element. On the other hand,

using the spleen meridian, may intensify the fire elements energy which can be beneficial in this instance. Meridian                               deep energy                      Point of Influence Lu Wood Lu11 Co Wood Co3

content_hebrew:
LU YIN XU     - הנקודה KID 10 תחזק את היין של הכליות ויין כללי בגוף. הנקודה LU1 כנקודת התראה תחזק את היין של הריאות ובכללי את היין של הכליות. הנקודה KID 6 כמסטר של יין צאו מאי, היא מניעה יין למעלה. הנקודה  LU7 היא מסטר של CV והנקודה KID 6 היא נקודת COUPLE של  CV.  מאחר ומרידיאני האקסטרא מהווים את מאגר האנרגיה הטהורה והעמוקה ביותר בגוף שלנו , על מנת לעשות שימוש במאגר אנרגטי טהור זה עלינו לפתוח מרידאן אקסטרא, מה שמסביר לנו שהאנרגיה אינה זמינה וחופשית אלא עמוקה שאנחנו רוצים לחשוב האם להשתמש בה. רק אחרי שדקרתי את נקודת המסטר והCOUPLE נפתח מרידיאן האקסטרא והאנרגיה זורמת בגוף.
- הנקודה LU4 היא האחרונה לפני יציאת המרידיאן לאזור היאנגי. היא נקראת מגן הלבן, יש לה יכולת לווסת את האספקט הייני והיאנגי של הריאות.

LU DRY * תזונה לא נכונה, אקלים, סביבה לחה ועוד (שיעור שעבר).   * SP QI XU יכול גרום לLU או HT QI XU.
* כשהטחול בבעיה נרצה לבדוק גם את הכליות.
* אחד הדברים החשובים הנו אורך החיים שלנו. הגוף שלנו במהותו הוא להיות מאוזן. הגוף יכול לתקן דיסהרמוניה.

SP YANG XU - חולשה של T AND T, מתחיל להיווצר לי לחות.
- דיאטה של מוצרים קרים ואוכל לא מבושל.
- פתוגן חיצוני שתוקף את הגוף ונכנס לתוך הטחול. * לקחה הרבה אנטיביוטיקה -
* עצירות פלוס דימום מחריף לקראת הווסת - חסר דם, חסר יין

2. פנימי, חסר

5. יובש בעור, סבוריאה (יאנג שעולה למעלה), הזעות לילה, צמא (לגימות קטנות), דלקות חניכיים, חולשה כללית, חסר שינה, שתן מרוכז.   9. טיפול - לפתוח את הCV, CV 4, 6, הנקודה KID 3, 6,7, הנקודה ST 36 בצד ימין תחזק את היין של הכליות בצד שמאל בונה JIN, YE, הנקודה LU1. הנקודה SP 6, SP 12, בנוסף KID 10. גם LIV 9, גם HT 6.

KID YANG XU א. מחלה כרונית או ממושכת הגורמת להחלשה של הHT.
ב. מאמץ יתר למשך זמן ארוך מחליש את הHT. הרבה ספורטאים בילדותם נהפכים לבעלי חולשה בלב.
ג. מצבים נפשיים או אמוציונליים כגון: צער, יגון, כאב, מה שנקרא שיברון לב. אנשים שיש בהם יותר מדי שמחה או שמחה רגעית גדולה פתאום יכולים לקבל מכה לHT. הכוונה גם להתרגשות.
ד. HT BLOOD XU יכול לגרום לHT CHI XU.
ה. LU CHI XU יכול לגרום לHT CHI XU.   * הסיבוכים - זה יכול לגרום לCHI XU כללי בגוף, כמו כן לסטגנציות של צ'י שיכולות לגרום לסטגנציות של דם.
HT YANG XU    * ההסתבכויות הן בעיקר שהליחה עלולה להמשיך ולהיווצר, היא תתמקד בחזה ובתוך הלב ותגרום לסטגנציה בסירקולצייה של הצ'י והדם. זה מה שיכול להוביל לתחושות הכאב בחזה שמקרינות אל היד.

HT BLOOD XU 1. איבוד דם מתאונה בעקבות טראומה, דימום, לידות רבות, דימומים ווסתיים כבדים, כל גורם נוסף לאיבוד דם.
2. במצב של SP QI XU יש לנו כשל ביצור של דם. כאשר למדנו שSP QI XU יכול להיגרם על ידי דיאטה לא נכונה שתגרום לירידה ברמה הכללית של דם בגוף.
3. מחלה ממושכת, חמה שפוגעת בנוזלים בגוף, בJIN/YE.
4. מערך רגשי של פחדים, חרדות, דאגות שפוגעות בלב ופוגעות באיזון בתוך הלב, מה שיעורר פגיעה בSHEN ויפגע בתפקודי הלב, יפגע בוויסות של הדם בכל הגוף.
5. HT BLOOD XU יכול להיגרם מLIV YIN XU, LIV BLOOD XU, זה בגלל שהכבד מזין את הלב. 1. בעיות שינה. אנו רואים שישנה פגיעה באיכות היינית או תחילתה של דעיכה או שחיקת היין בלב מה שלא מאפשר לSHEN להרגיש בטוחה או במצב נינוח ואז מתחילות בעיות שינה. מאחר והאדם אינו ישן בלילה הוא יקום עייף, יהיו לו חלומות מאוד מציאותיים, הוא למעשה ממשיך את החיים בלילה. בגלל שהוא קם עייף הוא יהיה חסר מנוחה, קפיצי, כל דבר מרגיז אותו, הריכוזיות תפגע, גם הזיכרון, יהיה חיוור, יסבול מפלפיטציות. הוא ירגיש עייפות ומותשות, סחרחורות (אין מספיק דם), הדם נותן את השקט, מרכוז, ממלא ומזין, מרגיע ומעדן והוא בחסר.

HT YIN XU נורא קל לזהות סטגנציה של צ'י של הכבד- אנו נרגיש שבפנים של המטופל יש הר געש שיכול להתפוצץ כל רגע. הסטגנציה היא תסכול של הגוף, העץ רוצה להיפתח ולהתפרץ (אי אפשר להיות כל הזמן נחמד ושלו...), כך נוצר קונפליקט בגוף שמצד אחד רוצה לפרוץ ומצד שני מחזיק את עצמו. רואים את זה בדרך כלל בחריצים באזור העין השלישית.
זה מתרחש יותר אצל נשים שהתפקיד שלהן כאדמה לעשות את הסטינג בבית. הם צריכות לעשות באלאנס רגשי. א.      אמוציונלים – יהיה קצת דיכאון וחוסר מנוחה. יש התרחשויות מתחת לשטח, הכבד שלי הוא בסטגנציה.
ב.      מערכת העיכול – נמצא בעיות וחוסר עיכול, צרבות וזה בעיקר על רקע התקפת הכבד וכיס המרה את האדמה. תהיה נפיחות של הבטן ויהיה לנו ברור שהטחול והקיבה מעורבים, הם הותקפו על ידי העץ והם עייפים ולא מסוגלים להתחיל לעכל. דבר נוסף מאפיין שלשולים ועצירויות לסירוגין, התדר שמגיע מהכבד וכיס מרה למערכת העיכול ולמעי הדק והגס. התדר הלא רגוע, מתוסכל ועצבני היוצר חום.
ג.       מחזור חודשי – לא סדיר, הדימום של הווסת יהיה קרישי עם דם כהה, הציצי יהיה נפוח וכאב למגע. בית החזה לא יהיה פתוח, הסגנציה עוברת ללב.
ד.      אנשים שנאנחים – אחת הבעיות היא שאנשים מאמצים את זה כדפוס. זה בעצם שחרור, ניסיון להסדיר את מה שמתחולל בפנים. כשפוגשים את זה אצל ילדים צריך לעקור אותו.
ה.      לובוס היסטריקוס (תסמונת גלעין השיזף) – זה התפר בין הפנים לחוץ, אני רוצה להגיד משהו ולא אומר וזה תקוע לנו, זה הסטגנציה וחוסר היכולת להחצין ולבטא או חוסר היכולת להכיל את החוויה.  הסיבוכים: מצב של סטגנציה של הצ'י של הכבד יכול לגרום לעליה בלתי מבוקרת של היאנג של הכבד, כלומר יש לי סטגנציה אבל היא לא נותרת לעד, יש לה נקודות שהיא מתפרצת. אם זה עוד לא קרה ההסתבכות הנוספת יכולה להיות שהכבד וכיס המרה מתפרצים ומחבלים דרך הco CYCLE  באדמה ועד זוב דם.
דבר נוסף הסטגנציה של הצ'י של הכבד כותש את הצ'י של המחמם האמצעי ואז יכולים להופיע הרניות, טחורים. הצ'י מחזיק למעלה שהטחול אחראי עליו אינו חזק ואז מתחילים לראות שהאיברים מתחילים לצנוח. א.      לפתוח את הסטגנציה
ב.      לווסת את הכבד מבחינת האיזון של יין ויאנג.
ג.       לתמוך בטחול ובקיבה משום שהם תמיד סובלים כשהכבד יוצא מאיזון.

LIV BL XU תזונה - או SP/ST YANG XU או שהמחמם האמצעי אינו מקבל מזון כראוי, אין ממה לייצר דם ואנרגיה. האדם לא אוכל ולא מזין את עצמו כראוי- הגוף לא מייצר דם.
חוסר תפקוד של SP,ST,SI,CO. מערכת העיכול חלשה - האוכל הנו טוב אך האיברים לא מספיק חיוניים כדי לבנות מזה דם.
דימומים, אם הם סמויים בקיבה, במעיים, טחורים מדממים, דימום בין מחזוריים, דימום וסתי ארוך, ווסת כל 16 יום, דימום מתאונה, איבוד דם אחרי לידה. גם מיומה או פוליפים ברחם יכולים להוביל לאיבוד דם.
מחלות חמות - דלקת בפרקים, בקיבה, מחלת קרון. הדלקת היא בערה פנימית, זה מעיב על מערך היין בגוף. החום מאדה את הנוזלים, מייבש את הגוף. למשל דלקת ברחם שהיא סמויה בתקופה מסוימת (במיוחד בעייתי לגילוי אם היא בגיל המעבר), מערך הדם יכול להיפגע.
LIV QI STG - א. זה מעיד על כך שיש פלישה של העץ אל האדמה, הכבד שהנו עצבני, מתוסכל וממורמר תוקף את האדמה והאדמה לא מייצרת (סופגת את זה במעגל הבקרה). למשל בכיב קיבה/אולקוס יש החמרה אחרי שכועס ומתעצבן.  סטגנציה של הצ'י של הכבד ישבש את תהליך בניית הדם. פגיעה בראייה - הכבד נפתח אל העיניים, הראייה תרד באיכותה, כתמים מול העיניים (עצמים צפים מול העיניים), ראייה מטושטשת. במקרים קיצוניים יותר העיניים יהיו יבשות כ אין הזנת דם לעיניים. בנוסף במקרים קיצוניים יכול להתפתח פוטופוביה (לא מסוגל לשאת יותר מדי אור).
צבע פנים חיוור - אין חיות, אין דם, הדם נושא את הSHEN ונראה כאילו אין חיות בפנים.
סחרחורות עקב חסר - אין דם, O2 שמגיע לראש, למוח
השפעה על הגידים והשרירים - הם ייחלשו (לא מגיע אליהם דם), עוויתות בשרירים, יכולות להופיע תנועות בלתי רצוניות, שרירים שנתפסים פתאום.
נוקשות של המפרקים בגוף כי אין הזנה של דם (צריכים את הדם בשביל להיות מוביליים)
הציפורניים תהיינה שבירות, חיוורות, מתפצלות
באישה דימום ווסתי דליל, בהיר וחלש, אחרי הדימום יש כאב ראש עמום, לא מוגדר  סיבוכים:
א. הלב יפגע כי הכבד לא מזין אותו בדם - HT XUE XU
ב. רוח יכולה להתחיל ולתפוס את החלל שמותיר אחריו חסר הדם בכבד. חסר הדם מייצר ריק שיכולה לתפוס אותו רוח (יש סינדרום של רוח משתוללת בכבד) לחזק את הדם הכללי, הדם בכבד ולהבין מה שורש הבעיה ולתקן אותה (SP או LIV QI STG)

LIV YIN XU א. סטגנצייה של צ'י או QI XU כללי בגוף.
ב. חום בתוך הדם שנגרם על רקע LIV חלש ולא מווסת, שגורם לדם להתנוענע במהירות ובפראיות וגורם לפצעים בST. הLIV פולש לST , העץ הלא מווסת, אלים, פולש לST וחובט בה ופוצע אותה, נוצר כיב היכול לדמם, הוא חם, אחת הבעיות הן שלוקח זמן עד להחלמתן (רקמת הקיבה מגורה כל הזמן).
*  הST הינו מעבר בגלל שעובר שם אוכל ונוצר שם גירוי ממעבר האוכל. אם המזון הוא חומצי אני מגרה את הפצע כל הזמן ולא משקם את רקמת הפצע. אם המזון הוא לא איכותי, יותר מדי מתובל, זה מעורר, מתסיס, מגרה. אנשים שסבלו בעבר מכיב קיבה היו שותים חלב או יוגורט בגלל הקירור.
* המנהג הרגשי - בכל פעם שיש התקף זעם, כעס, כרסום פנימי, רגעי חרטה, תסכול, קנאה - כל המנהג הרגשי השלילי מטפח את הפצע, כאילו האדם אוכל את עצמו מבפנים.
- ילדים/ מבוגרים הסובלים מגירוי על גבי העור, או דלקת וואגינלית - אמבטיה עם חלב היא פיתרון טוב. החלב הינו בסיסי, מנטרל, מקרר ונותן פיתרון טוב. * הסתבכויות:
ליחה בתוך הBL יכול לפגוע בKID YIN ואם היין של הכליות נפגע יכולות להתחיל הפרעות של הSHENהFIRE לא מבוקר דרך מעגל חמשת האלמנטים (הBL והSI הם גם ביחד באותה שכבה).
הBL המודלק יכול לגרום לחום ולחות בכל הLJ, הוא יכול לגרום לדלקת ברחם או אשכים (וריקוצלה). הרבה גברים הסובלים מוריקוצלה סובלים מאיכות זרע ירודה. וריקוצלה הינה דלקת והזרעונים עצמם יש להם אספקט יאנגי והם צריכים סביבה יינית.
יכול להיות פטרייה בנרתיק, קנדידה, יש ילדות הסובלות בגיל הגן מדלקות בדרכי השתן,
הטיפול:
מטרת הטיפול היא לחזק את הBL, לסלק את החום, ליחה.
נקודות כלליות:
CV2,3,4 - הן מכניסות המון יין למחמם התחתון, הן נקודות MU של הBL,SI,TH  * בעיות בBL מאוד שכיחות בקרב נשים כי יש קירבה בין פתח הנרתיק ופתח פי הטבעת. הסמיכות יוצרת נוכחות של פסולת וזוהמה בפתח הנרתיק.
* גורם לזה:
